bioghist.p: Albert Rosenthal (1863-1939) was a painter, etcher, and lithographer from New Hope, Pennsylvania. Albert was the son of Max Rosenthal with whom he worked and studied from an early age. Formally he also studied at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris with Gerome, and later in Munich. The brothers Max, Louis, and Simon Rosenthal were trained as lithographers and lived and worked in Poland. Max Rosenthal emigrated to the United States in the late 1840s. He worked for P.S. Duval in Philadelphia. Later the Rosenthal brothers, now all living in the United States, opened their own business. In 1884, Max Rosenthal retired and his son Albert took control of the company. The firm was noted for their work in the development of chromolithography.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of over 840 drawings by American artists from the late eighteenth to the early twentieth century. Works are in a variety of media, including pencil, ink, charcoal, chalk, crayon, gouache, watercolor, and pastel. Subjects include portraits, landscapes, cityscapes, vignettes, cartoons, and illustrations. The collection is largely made up of the work of illustrators such as C.E.H. Bonwill, F.O.C. Darley. Louis M. Glackens, and Edward H. Potthast. Other artist represented in the collection include John Singleton Copley, Asher B. Durand, Winslow Homer, George Innes, Eastman Johnson, Christian Schuessele, Thomas Sully, John Trumball, and Benjamin West.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
